lead_paragraph: An inquiry barred the owners of a Russian airline from United Nations business, but they won a World Food Program contract to airdrop food aid in Syria.

byline.contributor: Somini Sengupta reported from the United Nations, and Sophia Kishkovsky from Moscow. Doris Burke contributed research from New York.
byline.original: By SOMINI SENGUPTA and SOPHIA KISHKOVSKY

headline.print_headline: Barred From U.N. Work in Graft Case, Russians Return to Airdrop Aid
headline.main: Barred From U.N. Work, Russian Contractors Are Back, Airdropping Aid in Syria

snippet: An inquiry barred the owners of a Russian airline from United Nations business, but they won a World Food Program contract to airdrop food aid in Syria....
abstract: United Nations has paid millions of dollars to Abakan Air, Russian airline barred from doing business UN decade earlier, to provide airdrops of humanitarian aid to Syria; tale of how Abakan became only authorized civilian provider of aid in conflict is tale that illuminates UN's bureaucracy and politicized nature of aid delivery.
